sen.j: 平高棟（高棟王）の4男で、桓武天皇の曾孫にあたる。
sen.e: He was the fourth son of TAIRA no Takamune (Prince Takamune), and also a great-grandchild of Emperor Kanmu.

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)13年（871年）に渤海使が来航すると、式部省であった季長はその接待にあたる掌渤海客使に任じられて、大内記都良香とともにこれに対応した。
sen.e: When Bokkaishi (envoy from Bokkai) came to Japan in 871, Suenaga, who was an officer of Shikibu-sho (the Ministry of Ceremonial), was appointed to the Bokkaikyakushi (attendant to the Bokkaishi) and undertook the duty with Dainaiki (Senior Secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs) MIYAKO no Yoshika.

When the Bokkaishi (envoy from Bokkai) came to Japan in 871, Suenaga, who was an officer of Shikibu-sho (the Ministry of Ceremonies), was appointed to the Bokkaikyakushi (attendant to the Bokkaishi) and undertook the duty with Dainaiki (Senior Secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs) MIYAKO no Yoshika.

When an envoy from Balhae came to Japan in 871, Suenaga, who was the Junior Secretary of the Shikibu-sho (the Ministry of Ceremonial) at that time, was appointed to an attendant for the envoy to welcome them, and he and MIYAKO no Yoshika, who was the Dainaiki (the senior secretary of the Ministry of Central Affairs), undertook this duty.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 陽成天皇の元慶年間に兵部省兼伊勢国国司となり、元慶の乱後に近衛府兼陸奥国守に遷る。
sen.e: During the Gangyo period ruled by Emperor Yozei, he was appointed to the Hyobusho (ministry of military) and Ise no kuni Kokushi (the governor of Ise Province), however, after the Gangyo War, he was transferred to the Konoefu (the Headquarter of the Inner Palace Guards) and Mutsu no kuni no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province).

During the Gangyo era, which was the time of Emperor Yozei, he was appointed to the Junior Assistant Minister of the Hyobunosho (Ministry of Military) and the governor of Ise Province at the same time, and then he was appointed as the Provisional Minor Captain of the Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards) and the governor of Mutsu Province after the Gangyo War.

sen.j: 菅原道真と早くから親交があり、阿衡の紛議の際にはともに意見書を提出している。
sen.e: He had enjoyed the friendship of SUGAWARA no Michizane since his youth, and in the Ako Incident, they worked together to organize their opinions and submitted a report.
He had enjoyed the friendship of SUGAWARA no Michizane since his youth, and in the Ako Incident, they worked together to organize their opinions and submitted a report.
He had a long friendship with SUGAWARA no Michizane, and they worked together to organize their opinions and submitted a report when the Ako Incident occurred.

sen.j: その後、宇多天皇・源能有の側近として重用され、東大寺俗別当・弁官・弁官を歴任する。
sen.e: Afterwards, he was trusted and promoted to a close aid by Emperor Uda and MINAMOTO no Yoshiari, and successively hold posts of the Todaji-zokubetto (post in Todai-ji Temple) and Benkan (officer of the Oversight Department: division of the daijokan responsible for controlling central and provincial governmental offices).
sen.cmt: 弁官が2回記載されていますが，一回で訳しました。
sen.e: Afterwards, he was trusted and promoted as a close aid by Emperor Uda and MINAMOTO no Yoshiari, and successively held posts of the Todaji-zokubetto (post in Todai-ji Temple) and Benkan (officer of the Oversight Department: division of the daijokan responsible for controlling central and provincial governmental offices).

Afterwards, he was trusted by Emperor Uda and MINAMOTO no Yoshiari and promoted to a close aide of them, and he also held various positions including the Zokubetto (the non-priest administrator) of Todai-ji Temple, the Uchuben (Middle Controller of the Right of the Department of State), and the Sachuben (Middle Controller of the Left of the Department of State).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 特に寛平7年（895年）に能有が五畿内諸国別当に任じられると、山城国問民苦使に任じられて、権門による土地兼併が激しい同国の実情を調査して地方行政の改革と農民救済策をまとめた。
sen.e: With the appointment of Yoshiari to the Gokinai-shokoku-betto (a chief officer of the five capital provinces surrounding Kyoto) in 895, he was appointed to the Monmingushi (an envoy to investigate civil demands and discontent) of the Yamashiro Province, and after an investigation on the province, where the tochikempei (privatization of land) by influential families had been rampant, he made up measures for reforming the local administration and saving farmers.

With the appointment of Yoshiari to the Gokinai-shokoku-betto (a chief officer of the five capital provinces surrounding Kyoto) in 895, he was appointed to the Monmingushi (an envoy to investigate civil demands and discontent) of Yamashiro Province, and after an investigation of the province, where the tochikempei (privatization of land) by influential families had been rampant, he made up measures for reforming the local administration and saving the farmers.

When Yoshiari was appointed to the chief officer of Go-kinai (five provinces close to the capital: Yamashiro Province, Yamato Province, Kawachi Province, Izumi Province, and Settsu Province) in 895, he appointed Suenaga as a monminkushi (a position temporarily established to investigate people's demand and discontent) of Yamashiro Province, and he investigated the circumstances in this province, where lands were frequently annexed by influential and powerful families or clans at that time, to make up plans for a reform of the local government and relief of peasants.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました年号を補う

sen.j: 宇多天皇－源能有によって推進された寛平の治において、季長は菅原道真・藤原忠平とともにその実務を担った貴族官僚であったと考えられている。
sen.e: In the Kanpyo no chi (Glorious Kanpyo rule) promoted by Emperor Uda and MINAMOTO no Yoshiari, it is believed that Suenaga worked as an aristocratic bureaucrat who took charge of the practical business along with SUGAWARA no Michizane and FUJIWARA no Tadahira.

sen.j: 寛平8年（896年）に宇多天皇の従四位下蔵人頭（弁官・山城国兼務）に任じられ、翌年の醍醐天皇即位後も留任した。
sen.e: In 896, he was appointed to the Jushiino-ge Kurodo-no-to (Head Chamberlain with Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade selected from the Benkan, and concurrently hold the post of Monmingushi in the Yamashiro Province) of Emperor Uda's administration and remained in the post after the Emperor Daigo's enthronement in 897.

In 896, he was appointed to the Jushiino-ge Kurodo-no-to (Head Chamberlain with Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade selected from the Benkan, and concurrently hold the post of Monmingushi in the Yamashiro Province) of Emperor Uda's administration and remained in the post after the Emperor Daigo's enthronement in 897.

In 896, he was appointed to the Kurodo-no-to (the head chamberlain) of Emperor Uda with the rank of Jushii-no-ge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) as well as the Udaiben (the Major Controller of the Right) and the governor of Yamashiro Province, and he remained in these positions after Emperor Daigo ascended to the throne in the following year.

sen.j: 宇多上皇が新帝に出した『寛平御遺誡』において、季長は「深熟公事（公務に精通した人物）」として、藤原時平・菅原道真・紀長谷雄とともに重用すべき人物として挙げられている。
sen.e: In "Kampyo-no-Goyuikai" (a group of precepts for governing), proposed by Emperor Uda to the new emperor, Suenaga was mentioned as an important and trustworthy person along with FUJIWARA no Tokihira, SUGAWARA no Michizane and KI no Haseo who had a thorough knowledge of government business.

In "Kampyo-no-Goyuikai" (a group of precepts for governing), proposed by Emperor Uda to the new emperor, Suenaga was mentioned as an important and trustworthy person along with FUJIWARA no Tokihira, SUGAWARA no Michizane and KI no Haseo who had a thorough knowledge of government business.

The Retired Emperor Uda said in his document called "Kanpyo-no-Goyuikai" (Emperor Uda's injunction), which was offered to the new Emperor, that Suenaga was so familiar with government affairs that he should be given an important position, as well as FUJIWARA no Tokihira, SUGAWARA no Michizane, and KI no Haseo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: だが、醍醐天皇即位の9日後に急死してしまう。
sen.e: However, he died suddenly nine days after the Emperor Daigo's enthronement.

sen.j: 菅原道真から「宮中要須之人也、聖主所照不更具陳」（『菅家文章』）と評価された季長の死は、前月の源能有の死に続くもので、宇多天皇（上皇）に大きな打撃を与えた。
sen.e: While Suenaga was praised by SUGAWARA no Michizane as "an irreplaceable person not only for the Imperial Court but also for this country" in the Kanke bunso (an anthology of Chinese-style poetry by SUGAWARA no Michizane), his death, following the death of MINAMOTO no Yoshiari in the previous month, gave Emperor Uda a severe shock.

While Suenaga was praised by SUGAWARA no Michizane as "an irreplaceable person not only for the Imperial Court but also for this country" in the Kanke bunso (an anthology of Chinese-style poetry by SUGAWARA no Michizane), his death, following the death of MINAMOTO no Yoshiari in the previous month, severely shock.ed Emperor Uda.

SUGAWARA no Michizane praised Suenaga as he said in the "Kanke Bunso" (an anthology of Chinese-style poetry written by SUGAWARA no Michizane) that Suenaga was an irreplaceable person not only for the Imperial Court but also for this country, and Emperor Uda was severely shocked because he lost such an important person in addition to MINAMOTO no Yoshiari, who had passed away in the previous month.

sen.j: また、2人の相次ぐ死が菅原道真を結果的に政界の矢面に立たせることとなり、昌泰の変の遠因となった。
sen.e: These two persons' successive deaths eventually made SUGAWARA no Michizane take the brunt of politics and caused the Shotai Incident.
